results.title: Platypus Man
results.creator_credit: Kate Kennedy White, Mike Piper and Film Australia
results.brief_description: John Wamsley and Proo Geddes talk about their work at Warrawong and Yookamurra wildlife sanctuaries, which provide shelter for animals native to the Adelaide Hills, including platypus, from the predations of feral cats and foxes.

results.title: Ethics in the computer age
results.brief_description: Examines the loss of revenue suffered by the designers and producers of computer software caused by the pirating of video games. The focus is on the theft of “intellectual property” by people using computers in their homes. It also explains the dangers of hackers accessing sensitive information and the potentially life-endangering results of tampering with that information.

results.title: Your money
results.brief_description: This program presented by Margaret Throsby and via interviews with managers of various financial institutions suggest ways for the average man in the street to be informed about good money management. We need to look around at the various means available in order to obtain the best vaulue for money with our personal finances. The following topics are covered :- Budgeting, this ensures we see just where our money goes, Savings accounts, either a simple or compound interest account, Taxation and Inflation, the effects on the economy of the country and how they can erode our savings, Investments or enforced saving such as home ownership or superannuation.

results.title: Battle of Australia
results.creator_credit: Kim MacDonald, Les Neale and Today's Territory
results.brief_description: As an island nation, Australia was fortunate to be untouched by the ravages of war that shook Europe and Asia during World War 2, until the bombing of Darwin. For the first time in our recorded history, the horror of international conflict reached our shore. Australia’s isolation was no longer a guarantee of protection. This video presents historical footage of the dramatic events of the Japanese attack.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kim MacDonald, Les Neale and Today’s Territory

results.title: Women, wine and wellness: alcohol and your body
results.brief_description: Part 1 in a series about alcohol and its effects on women’s wellbeing. Even with allowances for the basic differences in size between men an women, women are more susceptible to intoxication and diseases of the liver than are men. Women may be trapped in a dangerous cycle when they combine the empty calories of alcohol with an unblanced diet. Even more serious are the results of alcohol abuse which include loss of judgement and addiction. No other credits available.

results.title: Federation films: Australian films from early 20th century
results.creator_credit: Chris Long and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: This is not only a documentary of moving image history in Australia prior to and on Federation, but also a tribute to the early pioneers of the motion picture industry. Discusses the role of the Salvation Army as the largest film making body during the earlier part of this century and provides short histories of our early cameras and their operators. Highlights include The Federation Parade, scenes from the Boer War and documentaries representing Australia as part of a “Greater Britain”. These early film pieces are superbly restored.

results.title: Problem solving & decision making
results.creator_credit: Leslie Hill and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description: This film examines the question, how do human beings make decisions and solve problems. It identifies and explains the two types of reasoning which have been identified as deduction anf induction. The differences between decision making and problem solving are defined as is the effect of bias. Some of the applications of improved understanding of these processes are identified.

results.title: Like nowhere else
results.brief_description: Like nowhere else graphically summarises some of the changes that have taken place in the Australian landscape since European settlement. We see environmental destruction resulting from the “develop at any cost” mentality that has shaped human relationships with the environment in this country for so long. We also see hope for the future in the growing community concern and the response of governments and industry. Narrated by Robyn Williams with music by Gondwanaland.

results.title: Youth and credit
results.creator_credit: Tony Wickert, Australian Credit Unions and Summer Hill Films
results.brief_description: A programme to alert young people to the positive and negative aspects of credit, by giving a comphrensive picture of the credit spectrum, and introducing young people to safe ways of handling credit.
